title: Information leakage - Private reports cached by Google

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello,
I have found at least two private bug reports cached by Google. (#10259 and #10257). 
Possibly more available 
Cached version is exposing title and part of the bug description

POC: http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:AnHgIn9Ed-UJ:https://hackerone.com/reports/10259%2Bsite:https://hackerone.com/reports/10259&lr=&hl=en&prmd=ivns&strip=0&vwsrc=1

POC2: http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:DXcBa6CGcTYJ:https://hackerone.com/reports/10257%2Bsite:https://hackerone.com/reports/10257&lr=&hl=en&prmd=ivns&strip=0&vwsrc=1

I have attached some screenshots 
Thanks

activities.message:
Hey @tisisire, 

Retracting disclosure is not something we do often, as putting the genie back in the bottle is often pretty much impossible. As the saying goes, "Once it's on the internet, it stays there". We could restrict google cacheing of recently disclosed reports, but that would just plug a very small hole. Any researcher could have copy-pasted the report, and can at any time post the full content wherever they please. 

We are currently working on ways to prevent the few cases of accidental disclosure that we have seen, which should minimize the potential for exposure, but other than that, there's little we can do.

Kind regards,
Dirk

Ok! If the problem arises from user behavior, its fine. Just take a closer look, if some of the mechanisms (like nosniff or nocache) have been implemented correctly, to disallow web spiders from caching sensitive informations.
These two examples,  never publicity disclosed, that why I found caching very weird.
Cheers

The two reports were publicly disclosed previously, but when the company (Detectify) shut down their program on HackerOne, the reports were accidentally made private again. This is a known issue with the platform, and while it seems odd, it's not malicious or unknown.

Thanks again for the report, though!
Thanks a lot for the detailed explanation!
i think a lot of people field as duplicate so disclose to avoid it

summaries.content: We have received a lot of submissions describing this behavior. Therefore, we have decided to publicly disclose the original report in an effort to expose the reasons why we can't really have any control over third-party caching services.

user.name: pieceoftoast
user.bio: A delicious, warm, golden piece of toast.
